choices.text: In the first pregnancy, only IgM antibody is formed
The chance of significant foetal disease is low, as maternal IgG antibodies do not cross the placenta.
IgG antibody titer is very low during the primary immune response
Maternal IgG antibodies cross the placenta only after the first delivery

questions.text: The consequences of Rh-incompatibility are not serious during the first pregnancy because:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Alloimmunization occurs when an Rh D-negative woman, carrying an Rh D-positive foetus (who inherited the D antigen from its father), develops an immune response against the fetal Rh D antigen.
  • When an Rh-negative woman carries an Rh-positive foetus, fetal RBCs with the D antigen may enter her bloodstream, usually during delivery. This triggers a primary immune response, producing mainly IgM antibodies, which are too large to cross the placenta. As a result, the first Rh-positive foetus is not affected.
  • IgG antibodies that cross the placenta are produced only after a second exposure, when a rapid memory (amnestic) immune response occurs (Rules out Options B, C and D)

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9593129/

questions.text: Which of the following neither predisposes an Rh-negative female to isoimmunisation nor warrants anti-D immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Advanced maternal age does not directly cause fetomaternal haemorrhage or isoimmunisation and is therefore not an indication for anti-D immunoglobulin.

The following events increase fetomaternal haemorrhage risk and thus isoimmunisation:

  • Miscarriage, MTP, ectopic pregnancy, hydatidiform mole
  • Invasive procedures: Amniocentesis, Chorionic villus sampling (CVS), cordocentesis, embryo reduction
  • Antepartum events: Placenta previa with bleeding, placental abruption, IUFD, external cephalic version, abdominal trauma (Option B & C ruled out)
  • Delivery-related events: Vaginal or cesarean delivery, manual removal of placenta (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Administered (IM) to the mother after delivery
Given when fetal Rh status is uncertain
Can be given up to 28 days after delivery

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding anti-D postpartum prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard dose is 300 µg, which covers fetomaternal haemorrhage up to 30 mL of fetal blood.

Explanation of Other Options:

Administered (IM) to the mother after delivery (Option A): Anti-D immunoglobulin is routinely administered intramuscularly postpartum to Rh-negative mothers.

Given when fetal Rh status is uncertain (Option B): When the fetal Rh status is unknown, anti-D prophylaxis is still recommended as a precaution.

Can be given up to 28 days after delivery (Option D): Ideally given within 72 hours, but may be beneficial if administered within 28 days postpartum.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of non-immune fetal hydrops (NIFH)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immune hydrops fetalis primarily results from red blood cell alloimmunization, whereas nonimmune hydrops fetalis (NIHF) stems from various conditions, such as cardiac anomalies, infections, or genetic disorders, which disrupt the fetus's fluid regulation.

Fetal anaemia is a key feature of immune hydrops, caused by Rh incompatibility, not NIFH.

NIFH is characterised by:

  • Increased skin thickness (> 5 mm) / skin oedema (first sign seen on USG)- Ruled out Option A
  • Placental enlargement- Ruled out Option C
  • Pleural effusion- Ruled out Option B
  • Ascites
  • The fetus is in Buddha position with a halo around the head.

questions.text: A 26-year-old Rh-negative woman delivers a Rh-positive baby. To determine the appropriate dose of anti-D immunoglobulin for postpartum prophylaxis, which of the following tests is used to detect and quantify feto-maternal haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Kleihauer-Betke test is used to detect fetal RBCs in maternal circulation by taking advantage of fetal haemoglobin's resistance to acid elution.
  • Maternal RBCs lose haemoglobin and appear as pale "ghost cells," while fetal RBCs retain haemoglobin and stain bright pink.
  • The number of fetal RBCs allows calculation of the volume of feto-maternal haemorrhage and guides anti-D immunoglobulin dosing.

Explanation of Other Options:

Apt test (or) Singer's Alkali denaturation test (Options B & D): This test is based on the resistance of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) to denaturation by alkaline solutions (NaOH), as compared to adult hemoglobin (HbA), but it is used to distinguish fetal blood from maternal blood in vaginal bleeding, not for quantifying fetal RBCs in maternal blood.

Coombs test (Option C): Detects antibodies bound to RBCs (used for diagnosing hemolytic disease of the newborn, not quantifying fetal cells).

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430876/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK224297/

Repeat anti-D antibody titers after 4 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 12 weeks' gestation undergoes routine prenatal testing. Her blood group is A-ve, and her anti-D antibody titer is reported as 1:4. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In an Rh-negative mother with anti-D antibodies (titer 1:4), alloimmunisation has already occurred. A titer of 1:4 is below the critical level (critical titer  ≥ 1:16 or anti-D level >10 IU/mL in most centres).
